roles.note: The matched items all have the same status as arguments/semantic roles.There are passives(6a) The paint is matched (by the wallpaper)(6b) The wallpaper is matched (by the paint)but these are adjectival, not verbal, as the tests show: The paint was unmatched The paint is well matched*At noon, the paint was matched by the wallpaperTherefore, (6) are predicative sentences, and the participle is an adjective, just like "peeling." So the (optional) by-phrase is an adverbial; the noun in the by-phrase is not an A0 (agent) argument.(6a) The paint is [matched (by the wallpaper)] AdjP(6b) The wallpaper is [matched (by the paint)] AdjP (And therefore these cases are not to be tagged--Paul)

example.name: basic transitive
example.text: The architect matched the paint and the wallpaper

example.name: with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint with the wallpaper

example.name: inverted with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper with the paint

example.name: to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint to the wallpaper

example.name: inverted to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper to the paint

example.name: unaccusative
example.text: The paint and the wallpaper matched

example.name: tricky
example.text: The company matched Kodak's higher prices.
example.note: The idea here is that the second Arg1 (presumably the company's prices) is unstated but fairly easily recoverable. This happens a lot in real usage.)

roleset.name: match up

roles.note: Add as many arg1s as needed

example.name: Without agent
example.text: When someone does n't do as well as they had hoped in a tea competition , they try to figure out [why]-1 their tea did n't match up with that of other growers *WHADVP*-1.

example.name: With agent
example.text: When I left him alone, he matched up the letters.

roleset.note: Added based on example in Brown corpus. similar to 'match.01'. Corresponds to VNcls amalgamate-22.2-1. Added by Julia.

frameset.note: Frames for MATCH.01 as developed by Christiane Fellbaum andrefined by Martha Palmer and Paul Kingsbury
